title: Stevens–Bruxner ministry (1932–1935)
text:
The Stevens–Bruxner ministry (1932–1935) or First Stevens–Bruxner ministry or First Stevens ministry was the 46th ministry of the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Government">New South Wales Government</a>, and was led by the 25th <a href="Premier%20of%20New%20South%20Wales">Premier</a>, <a href="Bertram%20Stevens%20%28politician%29">Bertram Stevens</a>, in a <a href="United%20Australia%20Party">United Australia Party</a> <a href="Coalition%20%28Australia%29">coalition</a> with the <a href="National%20Party%20of%20Australia%20%E2%80%93%20NSW">Country Party</a>, that was led by <a href="Lieutenant-Colonel">Lieutenant-Colonel</a> <a href="Michael%20Bruxner">Michael Bruxner</a>, <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a>. The ministry was one of three occasions when the Government was led by Stevens, as Premier; and one of four occasions where Bruxner served as Deputy Premier.
Stevens was first elected to the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Legislative%20Assembly">New South Wales Legislative Assembly</a> in 1927 and served continuously until 1940. Having served as a senior minister in the <a href="Bavin%20ministry">Bavin ministry</a>, following the defeat of the <a href="Nationalist%20Party%20of%20Australia">Nationalist</a> coalition led by Bavin, who was in poor health, at the <a href="1930%20New%20South%20Wales%20state%20election">1930 state election</a>, Stevens was elected leader of the newly formed United Australia Party in New South Wales and became <a href="Leader%20of%20the%20Opposition%20%28New%20South%20Wales%29">Leader of the Opposition</a>. Bruxner was first elected to the Assembly in 1920 and served continuously until 1962. Initially a member of the <a href="Progressive%20Party%20%281920%29">Progressive Party</a>, he served as <a href="Leader%20of%20the%20New%20South%20Wales%20National%20Party">party leader</a> in opposition between 1922 and 1925; and resumed leadership in 1932, following the resignation of his successor, <a href="Ernest%20Buttenshaw">Ernest Buttenshaw</a>. By this stage, the party was renamed as the Country Party.
This ministry covers the period from 13 May 1932 when, as a result of the <a href="Lang%20Dismissal%20Crisis">Lang Dismissal Crisis</a>, the <a href="Governor%20of%20New%20South%20Wales">Governor of New South Wales</a>, <a href="Philip%20Game">Philip Game</a> used the <a href="reserve%20power">reserve power</a> of <a href="The%20Crown">The Crown</a> to remove <a href="Jack%20Lang%20%28Australian%20politician%29">Jack Lang</a> as Premier. The ministry served until 10 February 1935 when the <a href="1935%20New%20South%20Wales%20state%20election">1935 state election</a> saw the Stevens–Bruxner coalition re-elected for a subsequent term.
Composition of ministry.
In the first arrangement, lasting just two days, Stevens was the only Member of Government pending formation of the full ministry as a result of the turmoil following the dismissal of Lang and his <a href="Lang%20ministry%20%281930-1932%29">third ministry</a>. The composition of the ministry was announced by Premier Stevens on 16 May 1932 and covers a period of a little over one month as an "emergency ministry" up until 17 June 1932 when the outcome of the <a href="1932%20New%20South%20Wales%20state%20election">1932 state election</a> was determined. At that point, a minor reshuffle of the ministry was effected.
Ministers are members of the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Legislative%20Assembly">Legislative Assembly</a> unless otherwise noted.
